raw_text:
Concerns over Windows ATMs
 
 Cash machine networks could soon be more susceptible to computer viruses, a security firm has warned.
 
 The warning is being issued because many banks are starting to use the Windows operating system in machines. Already there have been four incidents in which Windows viruses have disrupted networks of cash machines running the Microsoft operating system. But banking experts say the danger is being overplayed and that the risks of infection and disruption are small.
 
 For many years the venerable IBM operating system, known as OS/2, has been the staple software used to power many of the 1.4m cash machines in operation around the world. But IBM will end support for OS/2 in 2006 which is forcing banks to look for alternatives. There are also other pressures making banks turn to Windows said Dominic Hirsch, managing director of financial analysis firm Retail Banking Research.
 
 He said many cash machines will also have to be upgraded to make full use of the new Europay, Mastercard and Visa credit cards that use computer chips instead of magnetic stripes to store data. US laws that demand disabled people get equal access to information will also force banks to make their cash machines more versatile and able to present information in different ways. Todd Thiemann, spokesman for anti-virus firm Trend Micro, said the move to Windows in cash machines was not without risks. Mr Thiemann said research by the TowerGroup showed that 70% of new cash machines being installed were Windows based.
 
 Already, he said, there have been four incidents in which cash machines have been unavailable for hours due to viruses affecting the network of the bank that owns them.
 
 In January 2003 the Slammer worm knocked out 13,000 cash machines of the Bank of America and many of those operated by the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. In August of the same year, cash machines of two un-named banks were put out of action for hours following an infection by the Welchia worm. Incidents like this happen, said Mr Thiemann, because when banks start using Windows cash machines they also change the networking technology used to link the devices to their back office computers. This often means that all the cash machines and computers in a bank share the same data network. "This could mean that cash machines get caught up in the viruses that are going around because they have a common transmission system," he said. "Banks need to consider protection as part of the investment to maintain the security of that network," Mr Thiemann told BBC News Online.
 
 But Mr Hirsch from Retail Banking Research said the number of cash machines actually at risk was low because so few were upgraded every year.
 
 Currently, he said, a cash machine has a lifetime of up to 10 years which means that only about 10% of all ATMs get swapped for a newer model every year. "Windows cash machines have been around for several years," he said. "Most banks simply upgrade as part of their usual replacement cycle." "In theory there is a bigger threat with Windows than OS/2," he said, "but I do not think that the banks are hugely concerned at the moment." "It's pretty unusual to hear about virus problems with ATMs," he said. The many different security systems built-in to cash machines meant there was no chance that a virus could cause them to start spitting out cash spontaneously, he said. Banks were more likely to be worried about internal networks being overwhelmed by worms and viruses and customers not being able to get cash out at all, he added. A spokesman for the Association of Payment and Clearing Services (Apacs) which represents the UK's payments industry said the risk from viruses was minimal. "There's no concern that there's going to be any type of virus hitting the UK networks," he said. Risks of infection were small because the data networks that connect UK cash machines together and the operators of the ATMs themselves were a much smaller and tightly-knit community than in the US where viruses have struck.
llama3.2:1b: Concerns over Windows ATMs have been raised by security firm Trend Micro, which claims there is a risk of computer viruses disrupting bank-operated cash machine networks due to their use of the operating system.
However, many banks are using Windows-based systems, and experts say the risks of infection and disruption are small.
Cash machines may need to be upgraded or replaced every 10 years, but this does not increase the risk.
The Association of Payment and Clearing Services (Apacs) has stated there is no concern about viruses hitting UK networks.
llama3.2:3b: Many banks are switching to Windows operating systems for their cash machines, which could make them more vulnerable to computer viruses.
There have been four incidents of Windows viruses disrupting cash machine networks worldwide.
However, banking experts say the risks are being overplayed and that the number of affected machines is low due to infrequent upgrades.
Upgrades are also driven by new Europay, Mastercard, and Visa credit cards that use computer chips instead of magnetic stripes, as well as US laws requiring equal access for disabled people.
gemma2:2b: Banks are switching from IBM OS/2 to Windows operating systems for their ATMs, causing concerns about computer viruses disrupting these machines.

While incidents like the Slammer worm and Welchia worm impacted cash machine networks in the past, experts note that only a small percentage of machines get upgraded annually and most banks already incorporate robust security features to prevent spontaneous cash releases.
The overall risk remains low as traditional ATM network vulnerabilities are considered less likely compared to internal data-sharing issues affecting bank operations.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The article discusses security concerns surrounding Windows-based ATM systems, noting that banking experts believe these systems are not at immediate risk due to their relatively low vulnerability compared to traditional OS/2-based systems.
However, Dominic Hirsch from Retail Banking Research suggests that banks may be overestimating the potential for infection and disruption in cash machine networks.

The article provides specific instances of Windows viruses affecting cash machines in various countries and highlights the increased risk associated with switching to a newer operating system like Windows due to legal or technological pressures.
Overall, it emphasizes the importance of carefully evaluating both technical specifications and regulatory considerations when making financial services decisions.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Windows operating systems are becoming prevalent on ATMs, leading to concerns over security vulnerabilities.
Despite four reported incidents involving Windows-based machines, experts argue these risks are exaggerated.
Future cash machines will likely face increased exposure due to network integration and changes required for new card technologies.
A 70% market share suggests widespread adoption of Windows in cash machines, though upgrades occur infrequently.
The risk primarily concerns the commonality of data networks connecting devices, which could lead to widespread infections.
Although viruses pose a threat to internal networks and operators' systems, ATM security is robust due to built-in safeguards.
qwen2.5:3b: Concerns over Windows ATMs are growing as banks increasingly use Microsoft's operating system.
Four incidents involving Windows viruses disrupting networks have occurred, though banking experts argue these risks are small.
Many banks will switch to Windows due to OS/2 support ending in 2006 and the need for chip-based credit cards.

Todd Thiemann of anti-virus firm Trend Micro warns of potential risks: four instances where cash machines were unavailable for hours due to virus infections, linked to shared data networks between devices and computers.
However, Dominic Hirsch from Retail Banking Research notes that only a small percentage (10%) of ATMs are replaced annually, suggesting actual risk is low.
Despite these concerns, banks generally consider protection part of their security investments.
The UK's Association of Payment and Clearing Services also downplays the threat, attributing minimal risk to tight-knit data networks.
opencoder:1.5b:
Concerns over Windows ATMs

Cash machine networks could soon be more susceptible to computer viruses, a security firm has warned.
The warning is being issued because many banks are starting to use the Windows operating system in machines.
Already there have been four incidents in which Windows viruses have disrupted networks of cash machines running the Microsoft operating system.
However, banking experts say the danger is being overplayed and that the risks of infection and disruption are small.
For many years, the venerable IBM operating system, known as OS/2, has been the staple software used to power many of the 1.4m cash machines in operation around the world.
But IBM will end support for OS/2 in 2006 which is forcing banks to look for alternatives.
There are also other pressures making banks turn to Windows said Dominic Hirsch, managing director of financial analysis firm Retail Banking Research.
He said many cash machines will also have to be upgraded to make full use of the new Europay, Mastercard and Visa credit cards that use computer chips instead of magnetic stripes to store data.
US laws that demand disabled people get equal access to information will also force banks to make their cash machines more versatile and able to present information in different ways.
There are also other pressures making banks turn to Windows said Dominic Hirsch, managing director of financial analysis firm Retail Banking Research.
Todd Thiemann, spokesman for anti-virus firm Trend Micro, said the move to Windows in cash machines was not without risks.
He said research by the TowerGroup showed that 70% of new cash machines being installed were Windows based.
In January 2003, the Slammer worm knocked out 13,000 cash machines of the Bank of America and many of those operated by the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.
In August of the same year, cash machines of two un-named banks were put out of action for hours following an infection by the Welchia worm.
Incidents like this happen because when banks start using Windows cash machines they also change the networking technology used to link the devices to their back office computers.
This often means that all the cash machines and computers in a bank share the same data network.
"Banks need to consider protection as part of the investment to maintain the security of that network," he said.
"Many cash machines have been unavailable for hours due to viruses affecting the network of the bank that owns them."
The many different security systems built-in to cash machines meant there was no chance that a virus could cause them to start spitting out cash spontaneously, he said.
Banks were more likely to be worried about internal networks being overwhelmed by worms and viruses and customers not being able to get cash out at all, he added.
A spokesman for the Association of Payment and Clearing Services (Apacs) which represents the UK's payments industry said the risk from viruses was minimal.

The risk from viruses was small because the data networks that connect UK cash machines together and the operators of the ATMs themselves were a much smaller and tightly-knit community than in the US where viruses have struck.

In conclusion, banks are focusing on upgrading their Windows-based ATM systems to provide improved security and increased functionality for customers, while retaining the current robustness of OS/2 at the cost of reducing the number of potential threats.
Despite the risks, banks are continually working towards a more secure and efficient banking environment.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise, but it does not provide any additional information or context about the concerns over Windows ATMs.
The text only presents the main points without providing further explanation or analysis.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The text outlines concerns over cash machine networks becoming more susceptible to computer viruses due to their use of Windows operating system, particularly in the US and Canada.
While four incidents have disrupted cash machines, IBM's older OS/2 system was already in widespread use around the world, with banks facing risks that were deemed small by experts.
However, Hirsch notes that windows-based cash machines are more prevalent than IBM, and Thiemann warns of higher virus risks.
Banks will upgrade to Windows cash machines but only slightly over time, replacing older models rather than continuously upgrading.
The risk is partially mitigated by tighter data networks and existing security features, with Apacs emphasizing minimal virus risks in the UK compared to the US.
Overall, while there are warnings about increased vulnerability, risks seem manageable given banks' practices.
tinyllama:1.1b: Despite warnings from anti-virus experts, concerns over Windows ATMs are overstated as banking firms are increasingly using the Microsoft operating system and there are no reports of infected networks or machines.

Despite being prone to computer virus attacks, cash machines running on OS/2 operating systems have been endangered only because banks are beginning to upgrade their systems, with many moving to Windows for better security.
While internal networks and customers not being able to get out of cashs are concerns, no evidence of infected networks or machines has been found.
The Association of Payment and Clearing Services (Apacs) also insists there is no risk from virus infections as the networks involved are much smaller than those found to be affected by US banks.

Incidents like this happen, said Mr Thiemann, because when banks start using Windows cash machines they also change the networking technology used to link the devices to their back office computers.

"This could mean that cash machines get caught up in the viruses that are going around because they have a common transmission system," he said.

The Association of Payment and Clearing Services (Apacs) in the UK also claims there's no concern that viruses will infect the country's payment networks.

Despite this, banks need to consider protection as part of the investment to maintain the security of that network.

However, only about 10% of all ATMs get swapped for a newer model every year, and cash machines have a lifetime of up to 10 years which means that only about 10% of all ATMs get swapped for a newer model every year.
hermes3:3b: Windows in ATMs; risks of virus disruption due to increased use.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Security firm warns that using Windows operating system in cash machines could make them more susceptible to computer viruses, following four incidents already affecting networks in 2006.
However, banking experts argue that the risks are being overplayed, with the dangers of infection and disruption relatively small.
Many cash machines will be replacing their current OS/2 software from 2006 due to a change in support.
US laws also requiring banks to upgrade for increased versatility will force them to adopt Windows systems further.
Anti-virus firm Trend Micro cites research revealing 70% of new cash machines being installed as Windows-based, leading to incidents where viruses affected networks for hours.
However, Retail Banking Research's managing director Dominic Hirsch contends that the number of cash machines at risk from infection is low due to a low replacement rate for ATM systems.
stablelm2:1.6b: A security firm warns that Windows operating system-based ATM networks may be more susceptible to computer viruses due to banks using Windows for their machines, despite four incidents already occurring with Windows viruses disrupting cash machines running the Microsoft OS.

Banking experts argue that risks are overplayed and say that the real dangers come from outdated software like OS/2 being used by many banks (less than 1% of ATMs get updated annually), as well as evolving security requirements for credit cards, disabled people's access, and shared data networks.
Anti-virus firm Trend Micro warns that moving to Windows in cash machines is not without risks.
However, according to Retail Banking Research managing director Dominic Hirsch, the actual risk of infection for UK banks is minimal.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Banks are increasingly adopting Windows operating system for their cash machine networks, replacing IBM's OS/2 due to upcoming support termination and other technological demands.
This shift has raised concerns about potential computer virus impacts on these machines.
Since 2003, four incidents have occurred where Windows viruses disrupted the networks of cash machines, causing hours-long unavailability for affected banks' devices.
These incidents suggest a risk as banks often share data networks among their cash machines and back office computers when using Windows.
Despite these concerns, experts from financial analysis firm Retail Banking Research and Todd Thiemann of anti-virus firm Trend Micro argue that the risk is being overstated.
They note that only a small percentage (about 10%) of ATMs are replaced annually, implying a low number of machines at immediate risk due to their extended lifespan.
Additionally, built-in security measures in cash machines prevent viruses from causing physical cash spillage or theft.
Banks appear more concerned about disruptions affecting customer access to funds rather than the machines themselves.

The Association of Payment and Clearing Services (Apacs) representing the UK's payments industry also shares this perspective, stating minimal risks from viruses on their networks due to a smaller, tightly-knit community compared to the US.
chatgpt-4o-latest: A security firm warns that cash machines using Windows operating systems may become more vulnerable to computer viruses.
Banks are transitioning from IBM's OS/2 to Windows due to IBM ending OS/2 support in 2006 and the need for upgrades to support new chip-based credit cards and accessibility requirements.
Already, four incidents have occurred where Windows-based ATMs were disrupted by viruses, including the Slammer and Welchia worms.
The shift to Windows also changes networking technology, increasing exposure to viruses.
However, banking experts downplay the risks, noting that ATM upgrades happen gradually and that security measures prevent major issues like machines dispensing cash uncontrollably.
While UK banking representatives believe the risk is minimal due to tightly controlled networks, concerns remain about potential disruptions to ATM availability.
